text: - My name is Laura Salinas.
I'm a startup solutions architect
working with machine learning customers.

It will be my fourth year
at AWS this coming August.

So I was studying computer
engineering at Boston University.

And then, I was recruited
to the AWS Tech U program,
which hires students, recent graduates,

and trains them for six
months into a technical role.
(light upbeat music)
And so the Tech U program has been growing
really rapidly over the past couple years.
I was part of the third cohort

in the United States to
go through the program.

So we were a group of 30
recent college graduates.
And it's basically sprint work learning,

so it's very similar to
being back in college.
So you're learning for six months

being taught by other
professionals in the field,
going through demo days,
and really putting that working muscle
into practice every day

in trying to understand
customer conversations,
trying to understand the products.

Some folks might not have
any cloud experience at all,
so Tech U, as a program,

will also teach you the
fundamentals of AWS cloud.
But yeah, it was a fantastic program,

and there's now cohorts
all over the world.
So it's a very busy program.
When you come out of Tech U,

you're what's called an
associate solutions architect.
You come in as an entry level employee,
and then you're placed with a team,
usually with an entry-level team.
So you're handling some

maybe lower level
engagements with customers.
And then, as you continue to grow
and kind of demonstrate an affinity
for one area or another,

you kind of can point that
into different directions
and maybe try out a different role
or kind of go on for a different team

that supports a different
type of customers
and the like.

So what led me to machine
learning was really

just an interest in
leaving my comfort zone.

So when I graduated
from the Tech U program,
I was working mostly with enterprises
in a space where they're new to the cloud.
So it's very entry-level conversations,
mostly teaching folks what the cloud is
and how to adopt AWS services.
But I quickly kind of outgrew that,

the pace of that work
and became interested

in wanting to do something a
little bit more challenging,
a little bit more cutting edge

and stumbled upon this
machine learning team
that works specifically with startups.

And that's where I've been
for the past year and a half.
